awd_titl_txt: Computing for the Social Good: A Research-Practice Partnership to Increase Equity among Students and Parents
awd_abstract_narration:
A collaboration between Santa Cruz City Schools, the Santa Cruz Education Foundation, and Education, Training, Research (ETR), with additional researchers from Stanford University and the University of California builds on a previous NSF award for a research-practice partnership (RPP) to build capacity, and design and test a pathway for computer science (CS) education and computational thinking in 3rd-8th grade. Our RPP has identified three problems of practice that have relevance to national CS for All efforts, and are issues that district administrators believe can be addressed by the creation of a CS pathway: 1) inequity in academic literacy across demographic groups (the largest gaps between white and Latinx students), 2) increasingly segregated schools based on race and class, and 3) inequity in family access to and engagement with our digital society. This project will address these issues: 1) Motivate, prepare and support teachers to integrate equity-oriented computer science into core curriculum with supports for English language development, 2) Develop a K-8 pathway that attracts students and families by preparing them to be citizens who use CS for the social good, 3) Build family engagement and competence through computer literacy and leadership activities, and 4) Grow our Design-Based Implementation RPP that involves district administrators, principals, teachers, school staff, researchers, and education foundation board members. The project will generate activities and research knowledge that can be used to increase the number of girls and Latinx students who want to learn more computer science and have the capacity and interest to use CS for the social good. It will also be one of the first to generate and test units that integrate data science into K-8 and will produce a system for preparing K-8 teachers to infuse equity-oriented computer science education into their curriculum. Finally, it will identify strategies that schools can use to engage families and increase parents' confidence and competence to become leaders at their children's school and use computing to advance their own education and career.

This project will contribute to our understanding of: 1) How to prepare and support K-8 teachers to infuse equity-oriented CS into their curriculum including which concepts are difficult for teachers to understand and integrate, and whether a social justice angle is motivating to them, 2) Which CS and computational thinking concepts can be used to support academic literacy and language development in K-8, 3) How CS for the social good can be used as a tool for identity exploration and to foster youth and parent leadership, 4) Which strategies will effectively engage Latinx and low income families in their school and CS, 5) How to build an RPP, and 6) The process and outcomes of RPPs--when and under what conditions RPPs can contribute to CS for All, including the skills, strategies, roles and identities that are needed for both the researchers and the practitioners. Using mixed-methods and a design-research strategy, the project will focus on designing data science curriculum that support students' learning through problems that impact social good in their neighborhoods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to address unequal access to computer science education in K-8 across ethnicity and social class in one school district with large numbers of Spanish-speaking students.  To this end, we tested and refined four strategies: 1)  Motivate, prepare, and support teachers to integrate equity-oriented computer science into core curriculum, 2)  Develop activities to integrate of computer science into different subject areas, 3) Increase family engagement with computer science education in the schools, and 4) Grow our Research-Practice Partnership (RPP) which involves school district administrators, principals, teachers, school staff, and researchers.

Researchers worked with a computer science (CS) Teacher on Special Assignment (TOSA) to develop, test, and refine a set of strategies to prepare and support teachers, pre-service teachers, and school staff members to integrate CS into elementary and middle school. Effective approaches included professional development (PD) through large group presentations that demystify CS and computational thinking (CT) by showing the relevance to existing curriculum, small (grade-level) group meetings to design strategies to integrate CS and CT into core curriculum (including physical education), and coaching cycles where individual teachers write and implement lesson plans and reflect on what they learned. Researchers collected data from classroom teachers, library media teachers, and principals to understand their views of the PD, including what they learned, how it impacted their teaching, and how the PD can be improved. They also collected data from students about their CS identity and what they learned from participating in CS activities.

The RPP created a rubric for educators, teacher coaches, administrators and researchers to assess whether equitable practices are in place to ensure that the goal of CS for All is being achieved. The rubric can be used to assess the alignment between knowledge from both research and practice with how CS activities are implemented in classrooms. Best practice elements include support for English language development, identity exploration, students as change agents, personal relevance, challenging stereotypes, and family connections.

 

Broader Impacts

The project produced a scope and sequence for integrating CS into science lessons with support for English language development in K-5. It also resulted in computer science and computational thinking lessons that can be integrated into core subjects, some of which are available as a Choice Board that allows students to personalize their learning depending on their interest and ability. Further, the team created a rubric that teachers and researchers can use to assess equity in their computer science lessons and pedagogy.  Ongoing professional development was made available to teachers, including five school-wide PD days, fourteen coaching cycles that included six pre-service teachers, and PD for district-wide technology coaches. The results have been shared at multiple conferences for researchers and educators.

 

Intellectual Merit

This project contributes to knowledge about the conditions most favorable for K-8 schools to design and adopt computer science integration.  The findings suggest that a first-step of demystifying CS is needed for some teachers and administration and that teacher professional development must be integrated into existing school systems and structures. This requires a Teacher on Special Assignment who can provide coaching, co-develop lessons, and build support from school and district administrators. The research also suggests that physical education classes are a relatively untapped opportunity to bring computer science to all students. 

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2022
Modified by: Emily J Green
